questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with fever, left-sided chest pain, and dyspnea. Upon physical examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the left side. A chest X-ray reveals the findings presented below. A thoracentesis is performed, yielding a milky white fluid with elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and the presence of cholesterol crystals. Considering these findings, what underlying agent could be responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Mycobacterium tuberculosis

Explanation:

This clinical scenario suggests a case of pleural effusion, likely exudative in nature, characterized by symptoms of fever, chest pain, and dyspnea, along with diminished breath sounds on the left side.

A chest X-ray confirms a significant left-sided pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis reveals elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels and the presence of cholesterol crystals, indicative of pseudo chylothorax. This condition is often associated with tuberculosis (caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis).

Causes of exudative pleural effusion:

1. Pneumonia (Parapneumonic Effusion):

  • Causative agents: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Description: Develops as a response to infection in lung tissue, potentially progressing to empyema if untreated.

2. Empyema:

  • Causative agents: Often a complication of bacterial pneumonia, involving Streptococcus species, Staphylococcus aureus, and anaerobes.
  • Description: Pus in the pleural cavity, requiring drainage.

3. Malignancy:

  • Primary Lung Cancer or Metastatic Malignancy:
  • Common cancers: Lung (Mesothelioma > Adenocarcinoma), breast, ovarian, and gastrointestinal malignancies.
  • Description: Cancer cells invade the pleural space or induce inflammation, causing fluid buildup.

4. Chylothorax:

  • Cause: Results from thoracic duct injury or obstruction due to trauma, lymphoma, or surgery.
  • Description: Contains lymphatic fluid high in triglycerides, often associated with malignancy or trauma.
  • Distinct feature: Milky appearance due to chyle content.

5. Pseudochylothorax:

  • Cause: Occurs in long-standing effusions, such as those related to tuberculosis (TB) or rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Description: Characterized by cholesterol crystals in the fluid, linked to chronic inflammation.
  • Distinct feature: Milky appearance but with high cholesterol rather than triglycerides.

6. Autoimmune Diseases:

  • Rheumatoid Arthritis
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)

7. Drug-Induced Effusion

 

 

Pneumococcus (Option A): Typically causes an acute parapneumonic effusion or empyema, which is purulent and not milky. Pneumococcal effusions are often neutrophil-predominant and occur rapidly with pneumonia—less likely to show cholesterol crystals or be chronic.

 

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): Another cause of empyema, usually from post-pneumonic infections, especially in children or hospitalized patients. Like pneumococcus, it causes acute pus-filled effusions, not the chronic, milky fluid seen in pseudochylothorax.

 

Malignancy (Option C): Can cause chylothorax, which may appear milky, but that is due to triglyceride-rich lymphatic fluid, not cholesterol. Also, cholesterol crystals are not typically found in malignant effusions.

questions.text:
Match the ABG values in Column A with their corresponding acid-base disorders in Column B.

 


	
		
			
			Column A 
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. pH 7.48, pCO2 45, HCO3 35
			
			
			A. Fully compensated respiratory acidosis
			
		
		
			
			2. pH 7.32, pCO2 28, HCO3 14
			
			
			B. Partially compensated metabolic alkalosis
			
		
		
			
			3. pH 7.40, pCO2 30, HCO3 20
			
			
			C. Partially compensated metabolic acidosis
			
		
		
			
			4. pH 7.38, pCO2 68, HCO3 32
			
			
			D. Fully compensated respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Correct matches:

1-B (pH 7.48, pCO2 48, HCO3 35):

  • Elevated pH and HCO3 indicate metabolic alkalosis
  • pCO2 elevation shows partial respiratory compensation
  • Not fully compensated as pH remains elevated

 

2-C (pH 7.32, pCO2 28, HCO3 14):

  • Low pH and HCO3 indicate metabolic acidosis
  • Low pCO2 shows respiratory compensation
  • Not fully compensated as pH remains low

 

3-D (pH 7.40, pCO2 30, HCO3 20):

  • Normal pH with a proportionate decrease in both pCO2 and HCO3
  • Represents chronic respiratory alkalosis with complete renal compensation

 

4-A (pH 7.38, pCO2 55, HCO3 32):

  • Near-normal pH with elevated pCO2 and proportionate HCO3 elevation
  • Represents chronic respiratory acidosis with complete renal compensation

 

Complete compensation is characterized by the following:

  • Near-normal pH (7.35-7.45)
  • Appropriate compensatory response following established ratios
  • In respiratory disorders: renal compensation takes 3-5 days
  • In metabolic disorders: respiratory compensation occurs within minutes to hours

 

Compensation rules to remember:

  1. Metabolic acidosis: Expected pCO2 = (1.5 × HCO3) + 8 ± 2
  2. Metabolic alkalosis: pCO2 rises by 0.7 mmHg for each 1 mEq/L rise in HCO3
  3. Chronic respiratory acidosis: HCO3 rises by 4 mEq/L for each 10 mmHg rise in pCO2
  4. Chronic respiratory alkalosis: HCO3 falls by 4 mEq/L for each 10 mmHg fall in pCO2

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with severe substernal chest pain, difficulty breathing, and puffy swelling of the chest wall after multiple episodes of vomiting due to binge drinking. Upon examination, auscultation reveals a characteristic crunching sound. A chest X-ray demonstrates the presence of subcutaneous emphysema. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the next best step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Obtain a CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Perform an urgent thoracotomy

Explanation:

This patient's presentation suggests oesophagal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome), indicated by severe chest pain, respiratory distress, subcutaneous emphysema, and Hamman's sign (crunching sound). The presence of pneumomediastinum and respiratory distress aligns with Mackler's triad.

Immediate surgical intervention via urgent thoracotomy is necessary to prevent complications like mediastinitis and sepsis.

While antibiotics and oxygen are important, they do not address the critical condition directly. A CT scan may provide additional details but should not delay surgical management in this scenario.

Pneumomediastinum:

  • Pneumomediastinum is the presence of air in the mediastinum, the central compartment of the thoracic cavity.
  • Causes
    • Trauma:
      • Chest and neck trauma (blunt or penetrating)
      • Surgical procedures involving the thorax
    • Secondary Pneumomediastinum:
      • Esophageal Rupture: Boerhaave's syndrome
      • Alveolar Rupture: May occur due to conditions like emphysema or barotrauma (from mechanical ventilation)
      • Asthma Exacerbations
      • Air Dissection
  • Presentation
    • Mackler's Triad: This classic triad of symptoms includes:
      • Subcutaneous Emphysema: Crepitus (a crackling sensation) beneath the skin, particularly noticeable in the suprasternal notch due to trapped air.
      • Substernal Chest Pain: Patients report sharp or dull pain in the central chest region, which may be exacerbated by breathing or movement.
      • Vomiting: Can occur in association with the underlying cause, particularly in cases of esophageal rupture.
    • Hamman Crunch Sign: An auscultatory finding characterized by a crunching sound heard over the heart during systole, synchronized with the heartbeat. This results from the movement of air in the mediastinum.
  • Diagnosis
    • Chest X-ray: Shows the presence of air in the mediastinum.
    • CT Scan: Can identify the exact location and extent of the air accumulation and underlying causes.
  • Management
    • High-Flow Oxygen: The primary treatment involves administering high-flow oxygen, which increases the oxygen concentration in the lungs, facilitating the absorption of the trapped air back into the bloodstream.
    • Management of Underlying Causes: If pneumomediastinum is secondary to an underlying condition (such as oesophagal rupture), addressing that cause is crucial. Surgical intervention may be necessary in cases of significant rupture or perforation.

 

Administer intravenous antibiotics (Option A): Antibiotics should be started, but definitive surgical repair is the priority.

 

Provide supplemental oxygen (Option C): This is supportive care and may relieve hypoxia, but it does not address the underlying perforation or prevent complications like mediastinitis or sepsis.

 

Obtain a CT scan of the chest (Option D): The presentation is classic and diagnosis is obvious, surgical exploration should not be delayed for confirmatory imaging—"time is tissue" in Boerhaave syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after experiencing sudden chest pain and shortness of breath. He is a long-time smoker with no history of lung disease. A chest X-ray confirms a right-sided pneumothorax. Which type of pneumothorax is this patient most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Primary spontaneous pneumothorax

Explanation:

The patient exhibits characteristics of primary spontaneous pneumothorax, as it occurs without underlying lung disease, often due to the rupture of apical pleural blebs, and is commonly seen in smokers.

Types of Pneumothorax:

Type of Pneumothorax

Cause

Characteristics

Common Treatment

Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax

Occurs without underlying lung disease
  • Often due to rupture of apical pleural blebs
  • Seen commonly in smokers
  • Simple aspiration
  • Thoracoscopy if recurrent

Secondary Spontaneous Pneumothorax (Option A)

Associated with pre-existing lung conditions (e.g., COPD)

More life-threatening due to reduced pulmonary reserve
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Thoracoscopy or pleurodesis if needed
  • Thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion if surgery is contraindicated

Traumatic Pneumothorax (Option B)

Occurs during mechanical ventilation or resuscitation

Can be iatrogenic (from medical procedures)
  • Tube thoracostomy
  • Manage hemopneumothorax with dual chest tubes

Tension Pneumothorax (Option D)

Results from physical injury (blunt or penetrating)
  • Positive pressure in pleural space
  • Severe cardiovascular compromise

Emergency treatment with large bore needle decompression followed by thoracostomy

questions.text: A 55-year-old female with a history of COPD presents to the emergency department with sudden onset left-sided chest pain. A chest X-ray reveals a small left-sided pneumothorax with a depth of 0.5 cm. The patient is otherwise stable, with no significant respiratory distress and a normal vital sign profile. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Administer high-flow oxygen and observe for 24 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Administer high-flow oxygen and observe for 24 hours

Explanation:

In this case, the secondary pneumothorax is small and has only mild symptoms but no dyspnea; hence, the best treatment modality is to administer high-flow oxygen and observe for 24 hours.

Management of asymptomatic small primary spontaneous pneumothorax:

  • In cases where the pneumothorax is small (depth less than 2 cm) and the patient is asymptomatic, they can be discharged with follow-up scheduled in 2-4 weeks. (Option C)

Management of symptomatic or larger Primary Spontaneous Pneumothorax:

  • For symptomatic patients or those with pneumothorax greater than 2 cm in depth, needle aspiration is performed.
  • If the patient improves and the residual depth is less than 2 cm, they may be discharged.
  • If the lung is still collapsed or if recurrent pneumothorax occurs, thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion is done.

Management of secondary spontaneous pneumothorax:

  • For secondary pneumothorax less than 1 cm in size without dyspnea, patients are admitted and given high-flow oxygen, with observation for 24 hours.
  • If the size is between 1-2 cm, needle aspiration is conducted, followed by monitoring of the residual size. (Option B)
  • For patients with recurrent secondary spontaneous pneumothorax or large blebs found during imaging:
    • Thoracoscopy: This minimally invasive procedure allows for direct visualization of the pleural space, where blebs can be stapled to prevent future occurrences.
    • Pleural Abrasion: Performed during thoracoscopy to promote adhesion of the pleura, reducing the chance of recurrence. (Option D)

Management of Traumatic Pneumothorax:

  • Tube thoracostomy is the preferred treatment unless the pneumothorax is very small.
  • In cases of hemopneumothorax:
    • Place one chest tube in the upper part of the hemithorax to evacuate air.
    • Insert another chest tube in the lower part to remove blood.
  • Many cases can be managed with supplemental oxygen or aspiration.
  • However, if these methods fail, a tube thoracostomy should be performed.

Management of Tension Pneumothorax:

  • Insert a large-bore needle into the pleural space, specifically through the second anterior intercostal space.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed if significant amounts of gas escape upon needle insertion.
  • Leave the needle in place until a thoracostomy tube can be inserted.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He is experiencing severe shortness of breath and sharp left-sided chest pain. On examination, he has tachycardia and low oxygen saturation. A chest X-ray confirms a large left-sided pneumothorax. Vitals are HR: 120 bpm, BP: 70/40. What would be the most appropriate first step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Perform needle decompression

Explanation:

The first step in managing a pneumothorax is the insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 2nd intercostal space to evacuate the air, especially in a tension pneumothorax, which is considered an emergency.
 

Management of pneumothorax:

Needle decompression:

  • For patients exhibiting instability or associated symptoms, needle decompression is the initial treatment for a pneumothorax.
  • A large wide-bore needle is typically used.
  • The needle is inserted just superior to the rib in the second intercostal space along the midclavicular line.

Thoracostomy tube insertion: (Option A)

  • Following needle decompression or in stable pneumothoraces, a thoracostomy tube is inserted to facilitate continued drainage.
  • The tube is placed above the rib in the fifth intercostal space, anterior to the midaxillary line.
  • The size of the tube is determined by the patient’s height, weight, and any associated hemothorax.

Indications for surgical intervention:

  • Surgical options, including video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) (Option D) or thoracotomy, are considered for patients with:
    • A continuous air leak lasting more than seven days.
    • Bilateral pneumothoraces.
    • Recurrent ipsilateral pneumothorax.
    • Those in high-risk occupations such as divers or pilots.

Purpose of underwater seal chest drainage system:

  • Restores appropriate air pressure in the lungs.
  • Aids in re-inflating a collapsed lung.
  • Facilitates the removal of blood and other fluids from the pleural space.
  • Design Principles:
    • Prevents air from entering the pleural cavity during different phases of the respiratory cycle.
    • Ensures continuous drainage of air and fluid from the pleural cavity.

Administer supplemental oxygen (Option B): this is helpful, especially in small pneumothoraces, as this helps create a positive external pressure, enabling better oxygen perfusion with high-flow oxygen.

questions.text: A patient with chest pain and shortness of breath with a heart rate of 145 beats per minute is being examined in the casualty. Which of the following clinical features is not seen in a pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hamman’s sign

Explanation:

The “Hamman’s sign” is a crunching or clicking sound heard on auscultation in a pneumomediastinum, which is heard in synchrony with the heartbeats and is not seen in just pneumothorax.

Hamman’s sign:

  • It is a crunching or clicking sound in sync with the heartbeat
  • It is an auscultatory finding and is heard over the precordium
  • It is seen in pneumomediastinum

Clinical features of pneumothorax:

  • Symptoms:
    • Chest pain: pleuritic, sharp, severe, often radiating to the ipsilateral shoulder.
    • Shortness of breath (dyspnea), more pronounced in secondary spontaneous pneumothorax.
    • Severe respiratory distress in tension pneumothorax.
  • History:
    • Previous episodes of pneumothorax are important as recurrence occurs in 15-40% of cases.
    • Possible recurrence on the contralateral side.
  • Examination findings:
    • Observation:
      • Respiratory discomfort
      • Increased respiratory rate
      • Asymmetrical lung expansion
      • Mediastinal shift to the contralateral side
    • Palpation:
      • Decreased tactile fremitus
      • Hyperresonant percussion note
    • Auscultation:
      • Enlarged hemithorax with decreased or absent breath sounds (Option A)
      • Tachycardia (heart rate >134 beats per minute) in tension pneumothorax
    • Other examination findings:
      • Hypotension (Option D)
      • Jugular venous distension (Option C)
      • Cyanosis/marked hypoxemia
      • Respiratory failure
      • Cardiac arrest
      • Subcutaneous emphysema may be present in traumatic pneumothorax

Boerhaave's Syndrome:

  • Definition: Tear in the lower third of the oesophagus due to vomiting against a closed glottis, causing leakage into the mediastinum, pleural cavity, and peritoneum.
  • Presenting Symptoms:
    • Sudden onset
    • Severe chest pain
    • Abdominal pain
    • Subcutaneous emphysema
    • Shock
  • Signs:
    • Hamman’s sign:
      • It is a crunching or clicking sound in sync with the heartbeat
      • It is an auscultatory finding and is heard over the precordium
      • It is seen in pneumomediastinum
    • Mackler's Triad: Vomiting, chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema
  • Complications:
    • Mediastinitis
    • Septicaemia
    • Peritonitis
    • Emphysema

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male comes to the emergency department after a fall from height. He developed shortness of breath, tachypnea, and chest pain since the fall. A chest X-ray was taken shown below.



What would be the pathophysiology for the development of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Blunt trauma to the chest

Explanation:

The diagnosis here is of tension pneumothorax as per the history and X-ray image, which is caused due to trauma (blunt or penetrating) to the chest.

  • Pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of air in the pleural space, disrupting normal respiratory mechanics.
  • Types:
    • Primary spontaneous pneumothorax: occurs without underlying lung disease, often due to the rupture of apical pleural blebs (Option A). It is more common in males with tall and thin build and smokers, indicating potential subclinical lung pathology.
    • Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax: associated with pre-existing lung conditions (Option B), such as COPD, making it more dangerous due to reduced pulmonary reserve.
    • Traumatic pneumothorax: results from physical injury to the chest, which can be penetrating or non-penetrating. Includes iatrogenic causes (Option D) from medical procedures like transthoracic needle aspiration, thoracocentesis, and insertion of central IV catheters.
    • Tension pneumothorax: a critical condition where air enters the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure, mediastinal shift, and compromised cardiovascular function.

Pathophysiology of pneumothorax:

  • Normally, the pleural space maintains negative pressure relative to atmospheric pressure.
  • When the chest wall expands, the lungs expand outward due to the surface tension between the parietal and visceral pleurae.
  • Lungs have a natural tendency to collapse due to elastic recoil.
  • If there is communication between the alveoli and the pleural space, air enters the pleural cavity, disrupting the negative pressure gradient.
  • Pneumothorax occurs when air fills the pleural space, leading to lung collapse until equilibrium is reached or the rupture is sealed.

Pathophysiology of tension pneumothorax:

  • Impact on lung capacity:
    • As pneumothorax progresses, lung volume decreases, affecting vital capacity and lowering oxygen partial pressure.
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Symptoms can range from being asymptomatic to experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath.
    • Patients may exhibit tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and hypoxia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding normal pleural fluid characteristics is accurate?

choices.text: Normal pleural fluid typically contains over 3,000 WBCs/mm³.
The glucose level in normal pleural fluid is typically lower than that of plasma.
Normal pleural fluid pH ranges from 7.60 to 7.64.
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels in normal pleural fluid are similar to those in plasma.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Normal pleural fluid pH ranges from 7.60 to 7.64.
Explanation:

Normal pleural fluid has a slightly alkaline pH in the range of 7.60 to 7.64, which helps to maintain proper lung function and lubrication between the pleural layers.

Pleural anatomy

Normal pleural fluid characteristics
  • Appearance: Clear ultrafiltrate of plasma from the parietal pleura.
  • pH Level: Ranges from 7.60 to 7.64. (Option C)
  • Protein Content: Less than 2% (1-2 g/dL).
  • White Blood Cells: Fewer than 1,000 WBCs per cubic millimetre. (Option A ruled out)
  • Glucose Level: Comparable to that of plasma. (Option B ruled out)
  • Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH): Less than 50% of plasma levels. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with Parkinson's disease has been experiencing fluctuations in his motor function, To help manage these "on-off" features, new medication to his treatment regimen. However, the patient later presented with respiratory distress, chest discomfort, and diminished breath sounds on examination. Which medication is likely to be the possible cause of these respiratory symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Bromocriptine

Explanation:

In this scenario, the addition of Bromocriptine, a dopamine agonist, to the patient's treatment regimen is likely responsible for the respiratory symptoms he is experiencing. Bromocriptine has been associated with complications such as pleural effusion, leading to respiratory distress and diminished breath sounds due to its effects on fluid retention and vasodilation.
 

Exudative Pleural Effusion:

  • Exudative pleural effusion is the accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the pleural space, typically due to inflammation or injury to the pleural membranes, leading to increased vascular permeability.
  • Causes of exudative pleural effusion:
  • Pneumonia (Parapneumonic Effusion)
  • Empyema
  • Malignancy
  • Chylothorax
  • Pseudochylothorax
  • Autoimmune Diseases
  • Drug-Induced Effusions
  • Amiodarone
  • Methotrexate
  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Dantrolene
  • Hydralazine
  • Bromocriptine (Option C)

 

Amantadine (Option A) is primarily used for dyskinesias and has side effects like livedo reticularis, edema, and confusion, but not typically cause pleuropulmonary toxicity.

 

Levodopa (Option B) is the cornerstone of Parkinson’s treatment. While it can cause motor fluctuations ("on-off" effects) and dyskinesias, it is not associated with pleuropulmonary side effects.

 

Pramipexole (Option D) is a non-ergot dopamine agonist, pramipexole is less likely to cause pulmonary complications. It is generally better tolerated in terms of pleuropulmonary side effects compared to ergot derivatives like bromocriptine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male who has worked in the shipyard industry presents with shortness of breath and persistent pain in the right lower chest. On examination, there is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds on the right side. A CT scan reveals diffuse pleural thickening and nodular masses. A biopsy is performed to confirm the diagnosis. Which immunohistochemical marker is most likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Calretinin

Explanation:

The patient's history of shipyard work suggests asbestos exposure, a primary cause of malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM). Symptoms include shortness of breath and persistent right lower chest pain. MPM often presents with exudative pleural effusion, leading to dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds.

CT findings typically show diffuse pleural thickening and nodular masses. Immunohistochemistry is essential for diagnosis, with calretinin being a key positive marker that distinguishes mesothelioma from other cancers, such as adenocarcinomas.

Mesothelioma

  • Mesothelioma is a rare and aggressive malignant tumour originating from the mesothelial cells lining the pleura (the thin membrane surrounding the lungs).
  • Aetiology:
    • Asbestos exposure: The most common cause, with a latency period of 20 to 60 years.
    • Genetic mutations: BAP1 gene mutations.
  • Symptoms, and Signs:

Symptoms

Signs

Early symptoms:

  • Chest pain
  • Shortness of breath (dyspnea)
  • Pleural effusion (fluid buildup in the pleural space)

Progressive symptoms:

  • Chronic cough
  • Weight loss
  • Fatigue
  • Decreased breath sounds
  • Dullness to percussion
  • Pleural thickening
  • Investigations:
    • Pleural fluid analysis:
      • Malignant cells can be detected
    • Biopsy:
      • A thoracoscopy-guided biopsy is the gold standard for tissue sampling
      • Immunohistochemical staining to confirm the diagnosis (e.g., calretinin, WT-1, cytokeratin 5/6)
    • Radiological Signs:
      • Chest X-ray:
        • Unilateral pleural effusion (most common)
        • Pleural thickening
        • Pleural-based masses
      • CT scan:
        • Diffuse pleural thickening and irregularity
        • Nodular pleural masses
        • "Rind-like" appearance (encasement of the lung by thickened pleura)
        • Involvement of the mediastinum, diaphragm, or chest wall
      • PET-CT:
        • Staging
  • Management:
    • Surgery
      • Pleurectomy/decortication
      • Extrapleural pneumonectomy (EPP): selected early-stage patients
    • Chemotherapy
      • First-line: Pemetrexed + cisplatin
    • Radiotherapy

 

 

CD-117 (Option A): Also known as c-KIT, this marker is commonly positive in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) and some leukemias, but it is not associated with mesothelioma.

 

Chromogranin (Option B): It is used to identify tumors of neuroendocrine origin—not relevant in pleural-based mesothelioma.

 

Vimentin (Option D): While vimentin is a general marker for mesenchymal cells and can be positive in mesothelioma, it is nonspecific. It is found in many sarcomas and some carcinomas, making it less useful for definitive diagnosis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old female with metastatic adenocarcinoma of the lung presents with worsening dyspnea and a moderate-sized left-sided pleural effusion. After therapeutic thoracentesis reveals exudative fluid with low glucose levels and positive cytology for malignant cells, her symptoms improve, but the effusion is expected to reaccumulate. What is the most appropriate next step for long-term symptomatic relief?

choices.text: Insertion of a small indwelling pleural catheter
Tube thoracostomy without a sclerosing agent
Initiation of diuretics and oxygen therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Insertion of a small indwelling pleural catheter

Explanation:

Insertion of a small indwelling pleural catheter allows for continuous drainage of pleural fluid, providing effective and long-term relief from dyspnea. It enables home management, reducing the need for frequent hospital visits and invasive procedures. By alleviating symptoms consistently, it significantly improves the patient's quality of life.

Malignant Pleural Effusion

Prevalence

Second most common cause of exudative pleural effusion.

Common Cancers

Lung carcinoma, breast carcinoma, and lymphoma (responsible for ~75% of cases).

Primary Symptom

Dyspnea, which is often disproportionate to the size of the effusion.

Fluid Characteristics

Exudative pleural fluid with possible reduced glucose levels in cases of high tumour burden.


 

Diagnosis
  • Cytology of pleural fluid (initial step).
  • Thoracoscopy: If cytology is -ve & malignancy is suspected, thoracoscopy is the next step, often paired with pleurodesis via pleural abrasion.
  • Alternative Biopsy: If thoracoscopy is not feasible, a CT- or ultrasound-guided needle biopsy of pleural thickening or nodules can be performed.


 

Treatment

  • Treatment is mostly symptomatic, as pleural effusions indicate disseminated disease and curative chemotherapy is generally not possible.
  • If dyspnea impairs the patient’s quality of life and is relieved by therapeutic thoracentesis, further interventions include:
  • Insertion of a small indwelling catheter. (Option A)
  • Tube thoracostomy with a sclerosing agent (e.g., doxycycline 500 mg). (Option C ruled out)

 

Serial therapeutic thoracentesis (Option B) offers only temporary relief, with the effusion likely to reaccumulate, leading to discomfort and repeated procedures.

 

Diuretics (Option D) are not effective for managing malignant pleural effusions, which are typically exudative and result from underlying malignancy rather than fluid overload.

questions.text: A resident physician is preparing to perform a thoracentesis on a patient with a large pleural effusion. The patient is seated, and the procedure is to be performed under ultrasound guidance. Which of the following steps is crucial for the correct execution of the thoracentesis procedure?

choices.text: Insert the needle below the lower rib to avoid injury
Perform the procedure at the 2nd intercostal space in the midclavicular line
Ensure the patient is in a supine position for optimal access
Insert the needle above the upper border of the lower rib in the targeted intercostal space

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Insert the needle above the upper border of the lower rib in the targeted intercostal space.

Explanation:

To avoid injury to the intercostal vessels and nerves, the needle should be inserted above the upper border of the lower rib.

Thoracentesis

 

Indications
  • Diagnostic: Unexplained effusions, suspected infections or malignancies, differentiation of cardiac vs. noncardiac causes.
  • Therapeutic: Symptomatic relief in large effusions, pleurodesis preparation, empyema drainage, fluid reaccumulation (e.g., traumatic hemothorax).
  • Dual Role: Parapneumonic effusions may require both diagnostic and therapeutic thoracentesis to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Contraindications
  • Absolute: Bleeding disorders, active infection at the puncture site.
  • Relative: Mechanical ventilation, severe hemodynamic instability, previous infections or surgeries causing adhesions (may limit fluid removal).

Procedure
  • Conducted in a sterile environment, the procedure is usually carried out between the 6th & 8th intercostal spaces (Option B), targeting the midaxillary line for supine patients and the posterior mid-scapular line for those seated.
  • The needle is being put above the upper border of the lower rib. (Option A)
  • Guidance: Ultrasound-guided for improved accuracy and safety.
  • Steps: Skin prep → local anaesthesia → catheter insertion → fluid drainage for diagnosis or relief.

Complications

Bleeding, infection, pneumothorax, post-expansion pulmonary oedema (if rapid fluid removal).

Pneumothorax risk is higher in ventilated patients; and may require chest tube placement.

Management of Pleural Effusion:

  • Identify and Treat Underlying Cause: Managing the root cause (e.g., heart failure, malignancy, infection) is crucial for resolution.
  • Fluid Drainage: Drain fluid in symptomatic patients; for asymptomatic cases, drain only if diagnostic clarity or infection/haemorrhage signs are present.
  • Heart Failure: Perform thoracentesis only if diuretics fail or symptoms persist.
  • Chylous Effusions: Start with conservative management; surgical intervention if needed.
  • Parapneumonic Effusions & Empyema: Drain with antibiotics; small-bore drains (10-14 gauge) are often preferable. Consider thoracoscopic decortication if these fail.
  • Malignant Effusions: For frequent drainage needs, consider pleurodesis or tunnelled catheters. Limit fluid extraction to ≤1500 mL per session to prevent re-expansion of pulmonary oedema.

Ensure the patient is in a supine position for optimal access (Option C): The optimal position for thoracentesis, especially for large effusions, is typically seated (leaning forward) or in a lateral position. These positions improve access to the effusion and reduce risks like diaphragm compression and respiratory distress, which can be issues with supine positioning.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath and cough. Chest X-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis reveals the following findings. Using Light's criteria, which statement is true regarding this pleural effusion?


	Pleural fluid protein: 4.0 g/dL
	Serum protein: 6.8 g/dL
	Pleural fluid LDH: 280 U/L
	Serum LDH: 450 U/L

choices.text: It meets the criteria for an exudative effusion.
It cannot be classified without further testing.
It is likely due to congestive heart failure.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It meets the criteria for an exudative effusion.

Explanation:

To classify the effusion as transudative or exudative, we apply Light's criteria:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5

4 / 6.8 = 0.588 >0.5 (meets criterion)

  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6

280 / 240 = 0.622 >0.6 (meets criterion)

  • Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum LDH:

280U/L > ⅔ x 250U/L ≈166.67U/L (meets criterion)

Since the effusion meets multiple criteria for exudative classification, the correct statement is that it meets the criteria for an exudative effusion.

Radiological Investigation

X-ray:

  • 200 mL of fluid is needed for detection on the posteroanterior (PA) view.
  • 50 mL of fluid may lead to blunting of the costophrenic angle on the lateral view.
  • A homogeneous opacity with obliteration of the costophrenic angle is typical.
  • This appearance is marked by a curved upper border, known as the Ellis S-shaped curve.
  • Obliteration of cardiophrenic angle.

Ultrasound: More effective than X-ray in detecting fluid presence, showing a clear hypoechoic space indicative of transudate and moving densities suggesting exudate.

Pleural Fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Additional Tests for Exudative Effusions
  • Appearance description
  • Glucose level
  • Differential cell count
  • Microbiologic studies
  • Cytology

If Glucose <60 mg/dL Consider:

  • Malignancy
  • Bacterial infections (empyema)
  • Rheumatoid pleuritis

Standard Peculiarities

  • Heart Failure: NT-proBNP level > 1500 pg/mL indicates effusion due to congestive heart failure
  • Parapneumonic Effusion: Key criteria include:
  • Loculated pleural fluid
  • Pleural fluid pH < 7.20
  • Pleural fluid glucose < 3.3 mmol/L (< 60 mg/dL)
  • Positive Gram stain or culture results
  • Presence of visible pus
  • Tuberculous Pleuritis: Diagnosis confirmed by high TB markers in pleural fluid (adenosine deaminase > 40 IU/L or interferon γ > 140 pg/mL)

It is definitely transudative (Option A): It does not meet the criteria for a transudative effusion.

It cannot be classified without further testing (Option C): Sufficient data is provided to classify.

It is likely due to congestive heart failure (Option D): Since the criteria suggest an exudate, which is often associated with other conditions like malignancy or infection rather than just congestive heart failure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a known diagnosis of metastatic mesothelioma presents with worsening dyspnea and right-sided chest pain that is constant. Chest imaging is given below. What clinical finding is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Egophony at the superior aspect of the effusion
Bronchial breath sounds over the effusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Egophony at the superior aspect of the effusion

Explanation:

Egophony is a key sign of pleural effusion, particularly noted at the upper boundary of the fluid. The chest X-ray shows a right-sided pleural effusion, indicated by blunting of the costophrenic angle and increased opacity. The fluid compresses adjacent lung tissue, altering sound transmission. When the patient says "E," it may be heard as "A" over the effusion, helping to locate its upper limit.

Clinical findings of Pleural effusion

Symptoms
  • Cough, fever, and systemic signs depending on the underlying cause.
  • Pleurisy, marked by sharp, localized pain during breathing or coughing, occurs with active pleural inflammation but typically subsides once the effusion forms.
  • Constant pain, however, is often associated with malignant conditions like mesothelioma.

Physical Examination
  • Dullness on percussion. (Option A ruled out)
  • Decreased breath sounds. (Option D ruled out)
  • Diminished tactile and vocal fremitus. (Option C ruled out)
  • Egophony is most pronounced at the upper part of the effusion. (Option B)
  • Pleural Rubs can be heard during active pleurisy and may be confused with coarse crackles.

History and Diagnostic Focus
  • Comprehensive history to explore potential causes of pulmonary and systemic effusions.
  • Assess for comorbidities, medications, infectious disease indicators, and malignancy risk factors.
  • Congestive Heart Failure: Suspected with jugular venous distension, S3 heart sound, and pedal oedema.
  • Liver Cirrhosis: Considered with signs such as ascites and caput medusae.
  • Primary TB: Cachexia, cough, hemoptysis, extreme breathlessness, night sweats, evening rise in temperature.

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A chest X-ray shows a pleural effusion. Pleural fluid analysis reveals elevated protein and LDH levels. Which of the following conditions is the likely cause of this exudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Esophageal rupture
Explanation:

Esophageal rupture can lead to exudative pleural effusions due to the leakage of gastrointestinal contents into the pleural space, resulting in inflammation and elevated protein and LDH levels.

Causes of pleural effusion

Tranudative

Exudative

Both
  • Congestive heart failure (Option C)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome (Option D)
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • SVC obstruction
  • Myxedema
  • Urinothorax (Option A)
  • Malignancies
  • Tuberculosis
  • Pneumonia
  • Esophageal perforation (Option B)
  • Pancreatic disease
  • Collagen vascular diseases:
  • Rheumatoid pleuritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Sjögren syndrome
  • Wegener Granulomatosis

Pulmonary embolism

Drugs induced
  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Dantrolene
  • Methysergide
  • Bromocriptine
  • Procarbazine
  • Amiodarone
